Review_body: Diane Sherman (Sarah Paulson) is an overly protective mother to homeschooled wheelchair-bound teenager Chloe (Kiera Allen). Chloe grows suspicious of the pill her mother gives her.This is a nice little simple psychological horror. The script has a few minor flaws but I can deal with that. The pharmacist is way too stupid. It could have been fixed if she calls social services. That could have led to a tense scene when a social worker comes knocking at the door. Another scene is breaking the window. It's very unlikely to work and she could have just hit it with something like a hammer. When Chloe conveniently discovers everything, it would be more intense if she tries to placate her mother. Newcomer Kiera Allen is actually a pretty good actress and I would like her to try changing gears in her characterization. All in all, this is nice but it could be even better. It needs a bit more mystery. It could be smarter but it's still pretty good.

Review title: I'm not going to hurt you
Review_body: Chloe (Kiera Allen) was born with a number of disorders and is lucky to be alive. She is in a wheel chair and is awaiting her college acceptance letter. She is home schooled by her mother. And then PLOT SPOILER Chloe discovers her mother is giving her medication to keep her legs numb. So much for mother-daughter love and trust. Things escalate.Interesting story for just two main characters for much of the feature, of which half is building the characters. Nice twists. I think it has been done before, but it was well done here.Guide: No swearing, sex, or nudity.

That is something that is mostly true, right? We do accept the wisdom and the experience when it comes to what our moms know and do believe they only have the best interest in their mind. Review title: you don't even know that you don't know
Review_body: There have been quite a few thrillers about people who aren't what they seem, but Aneesh Chaganty's "Run" is still enjoyable. Originally planned for a theatrical release, it got postponed due to a certain pandemic, so it aired on Hulu. Sarah Paulson plays a mom who just might have a few skeletons in her closet. There were some clever tricks played throughout the movie, even if they wouldn't have gone exactly as depicted.Not a great movie, but watchable.

Review title: Does Chloe's mother have her best interests at heart?
Review_body: Diane Sherman appears to be a loving mother. She home schools Chloe, her disabled daughter, and is proud of her as she waits to hear from colleges she has applied to. She feeds Chloe only wholesome organic food and makes sure she takes the medicines for her various conditions every day. Then one day Chloe sees that her medication appears to be prescribed to her mother; Diane has an explanation but a seed of doubt has been planted. Chloe determines to find out more about her pills... what she discovered turns her world upside down as she must consider the possibility that her mother is the one making her ill.I found this while looking for a ninety minute horror film on Netflix; I don't think I'd classify it as horror even though it provides the scares it doesn't have most elements one associates with the genre. That said I enjoyed it more than I expected. The setting, and fact that Chloe can't walk, give a really good claustrophobic feel. The fear factor beats that on many horror films as rather than relying on a monster or maniac the potential danger comes from the person our protagonist should trust most... indeed until her accidental discovery she did trust her. Kiera Allen is really great as Chloe and Sarah Paulson impresses as Diane. There are some details that aren't exactly plausible but these can be put down to dramatic license; finding more realistic explanations for certain things would have slowed the film down. Overall I'd certainly recommend this to anybody wanting a good taut thriller but who doesn't demand lots of shooting, explosions and chases.

Review title: A rather intense and entertaining thriller...
Review_body: I hadn't heard about the 2020 "Run" from writers Aneesh Chaganty and Sev Ohanian prior to getting to sit down to watch it. I looked it up on IMDb just before watching it, hoping to get an idea what I was in for; so I read the synopsis for the movie, but not any reviews.Normally I am not one to watch an abundance of thrillers, because the genre tends to be pretty much a dime a dozen, but still with the chance given to sit down to watch this particular movie, I did so.And I will say that director Aneesh Chaganty definitely delivered an entertaining movie. The storyline presented in the movie was one that had me thoroughly entertained, and I enjoyed how the writers kept me in the dark, letting me guess as to what was really going on. And director Aneesh Chaganty managed to reveal more and more of the actual happenings in small bits and pieces, which definitely left me wanting for more, and it was such a good sensation when it dawns upon you what is actually happening."Run" is a movie that is driven by some great acting performances by the two leads; that being Sarah Paulson (playing Diane, the mom) and Kiera Allen (playing Chloe, the disabled daughter). And since there weren't all that many people in the movie, the pressure of delivering was bigger for the leads, but they mustered this with excellence.The build up of the storyline is good and keeps you wanting more, and I like how the director just gradually feeds you bits and pieces of the storyline, as it makes for a very intense movie.I was definitely entertained by "Run" and it is a movie that was well-worth taking the time to sit down and watch. The ending of the movie, though, was just rubbish - pardon my bluntness here. But that ending was just ridiculous; and no, I am not revealing it, as you have to experience it yourself.My rating of "Run" lands on a well-deserved six out of ten stars.

Review title: Suspenseful, glad I didn't pay attention to the complaining negative reviews.
Review_body: Once again I come to the conclusion I can't trust the negative reviews on here as after watching Run I just think the opposite of those reviews. I wanted to watch an engaging mysterious thriller story and that's exactly what I got, so no I won't complain about Run. There is a constant high suspense what keeps you very focussed on the movie. Sarah Paulson and Kiera Allen both did a great job playing their characters. 'Run (2020)' is centred on a wheelchair-bound teenager who, on the cusp of going to college, begins to suspect that her mother is hiding a sinister secret. For much of its runtime, it plays out as a sort of low-key (or, perhaps, 'realistic') mystery focused primarily on its lead character's increasingly cunning means of uncovering the truth. After a certain point, though, it dips into much more generic territory and takes the form of a much more formulaic thriller. After this point, the motivation of a certain character slips from 'almost understandable' to 'downright insane' and it loses almost all sense of nuance and, even, realism. Basically, there's a definitive villain who - despite having suffered trauma and clearly being in need of psychological help - doesn't feel like they can ever be redeemed. Naturally, this is a lot less interesting than what the film initially sets up. However, the picture manages to move past its mistakes because it's constantly exploring new angles of its generic events. A large part of that is thanks to the fact that it focuses on a disabled character (portrayed by a real wheelchair user), a perspective not often seen in cinema of any kind. She's smart, capable and resourceful; it's incredibly satisfying to see her overcome the increasingly difficult obstacles in her path. The flick is suspenseful and tense when it needs to be, taking cues from films such as 'Misery (1990)' to keep its audience right where it wants them to be. It's really entertaining, actually. It just trips over itself every now and again. It's ultimately rather generic in a lot of ways, which is a tad frustrating since it's so distinct and progressive in others. Still, it's a strong entry in its genre. It might not reinvent the wheel, but at least it shows it from another angle. 7/10.

Review_body: I watched a lot of movies and it had been a long time (over the pandemic year/s) since I have seen such a gripping thriller involving a family. In Run, a mother and a daughter's relationship starts to strain when the latter suspects her mother is doing ill on her. As you continue to guess what it might be, Run takes you by surprise. Review title: Suspenseful and creepy on a different level.
Review_body: 'Run' is a well crafted, tense thriller that hits you with shocking twist upon shocking twist.What happens when you suddenly don't trust your mom anymore, after she has lovingly taken care of you for 17 years? 'Run' explores this - with nail-biting suspense! This was creepy on a completely different level. The film's protagonist is Chloe, a paraplegic (excellently portrayed by real-life wheelchair bound actress Kiera Allen). Whenever a thriller features a character with a disability (or pregnant woman) the suspense is automatically elevated. 'Run' became more intense and suspenseful with every scene.Once the characters are set up, it doesn't take long before events take a turn for the worse, and Chloe realizes she's a prisoner within the confines of her own home. I don't want to do any spoilers, so I'm not going to delve too deep into the story. This is one of those movies where the ending couldn't come soon enough. Not because I didn't like it, but because it was so nerve wrecking that I could hardly contain my curiosity to see how it would end. Amazingly, the film simply never loses momentum. This is a rather disturbing psychological thriller, and one of the must-see films of 2020 (if you're into thrillers).Kiera Allan brilliantly carries the film, and Sarah Paulsen is superb as the mother, Diane. I thought 'Run' was excellent.Would I watch it again? Yes.

"Run" is a Mystery - Horror movie in which we watch the lives of a mother and her daughter who is home-schooled. The daughter starts to suspect her mother after finding out some evidence that she is lying to her. She will try to find out the truth but her mother does not want her to.I liked this movie because it had a simple but interesting plot, much of suspense in many scenes and very good interpretations by the cast. The direction which was made by Aneesh Chaganty, it was very good and I believe that he did an excellent job on made the audience feel what his main character being through and created a feeling that the audience is a part of the movie. Regarding the interpretations, both Sarah Paulson who played as Diane Sherman and Kiera Allen who played as Chloe Sherman were very good. Lastly, I have to say that I strongly recommend this movie to any horror movie fan because I am sure that you will enjoy it.

Review title: Effective thriller that will keep you anxious and on edge.
Review_body: 4 out of 5 stars.Run is a good thriller film about a mother Diane (Sarah Paulson) after prematurely giving birth. Her baby is born with several illnesses and disorders that will cause her to always need help and be medicated. As a teen Chloe (Kiera Allen) is homeschooled by her mother. While anxiously waiting to hear back from an university on her application. She soon discover that one of her medication may not be her own. Which causes her to dig up more information if her mother is really helping her or her mother is hiding something.Run is a effective thriller. Putting the audience on the edge with a poor helpless girl. Which she is unable to walk. Her mother sheltering her away with no computer besides her own. No cell phones. So Chloe is unable to really reach for outside help besides her mother. The direction did a good job in leaving you on the edge of your seat. Chloe trying to seek help while her mother is distracted with something. But moments later her mother is creepily lurking near.The plot may be covering similar concept grounds that lifetime movies have done before. But thrilling nonetheless. There is a twist that may shock viewers.Sarah Paulson plays a creepy obsessed mother really well. Kiera Allen also did a good job in playing a struggling daughter.The film does pick up the pace with thrills and suspense which may have you gasping for air when Chloe is trying to seek help away from her mother. Definitely a thriller worth checking out.

Review title: A mid-tier thriller with some unique elements
Review_body: Following the surprise success of his first feature film, the internet based Searching, up and coming director Aneesh Chaganty returns to the thriller genre for his second feature effort Run, a Sarah Paulson starring event picture that recently set Hulu streaming records in the United States when it premiered on the service in late November of 2020.A familiar film in many ways that is made to appear fresher thanks to its casting of wheelchair using actress Kiera Allen, who stars as the films main protagonist Chloe Sherman, Run isn't as inventive or effective as Chaganty's first effort behind the camera but it once more showcases a director looking at doing things differently in a landscape where the easy option is often taken.Unable to provide much in the way of shock or unforeseen twists and feelings that at times the story at the heart of the tale is leaning too far into the unbelievable, Run see's poor old Chloe discovering that her seemingly loving mother may in fact not be the parental caregiver that she had thought she was as Sarah Paulson's wide-eyed Diane starts displaying cracks in her outward façade and in her motivations.Paulson is effective as usual as Diane, even if she is prone to over play some moments in the film (yelling at some poor pharmacy customers, Paulson finds herself in one of the years more unintentionally hilarious scenes) while Allen delivers a career making turn as Chloe who is absolutely someone we as an audience want to see succeed as we go along her journey with her, one that will make her question her entire life and diagnosis up until this point in time.Working best in its quieter moments, especially in its early scenes that have an ominous and foreboding sense of dread and despair about them, it's a shame Run starts too lose steam in its latter section as a feeling as though a majority of its best moments have already come to fruition and the film is merely playing out a set of more predictable moments that will surprise no one who has ever seen a film of this ilk before.Final Say -A solid if unspectacular sophomore effort from Chaganty that can't hide its generic center behind the inventive casting and lead character development, Run ends up being totally watchable but far from memorable.2 1/2 glasses of wine out of 5.

Review title: Excellently made but we've seen this story too many times before
Review_body: I was a big fan of Aneesh Chaganty's debut film 'Searching'. It was creative, original and best of all it was a gripping and clever story. It was one of my few perfect 10 scores for 2018. So needless to say I was very excited for his follow-up film 'Run'. I really wanted to love this film, but I just couldn't. I enjoyed it, no doubt about that, but it never managed to grip me and put me on the edge of my seat needing to know what was going to happen next.The story was just a little bit basic for me. It felt like the kind of plot you'd find in a Lifetime movie. It was just simply made with much more class behind the camera and far better actors than those films typically get. The film does have a PG-13 rating which is usually a red flag of a very safe movie, however 'Searching' had the same rating so I wasn't too worried about that. 'Run' did feel extremely safe though. Any minor scenes of violence that do occur typically happen off screen for the most part. The pacing in this film also seemed just a little off. There are some very over-long and drawn out scenes with not a lot going on.The acting in this film is superb. Sarah Paulson gives her everything to the role. She's almost worth an entire extra point for the film all by herself. Also new-comer Kiera Allen in her debut film blew me away. I would never have guessed that she was new to the industry. There's some good stuff in 'Run' and it is made exceptionally well for the most part. I just feel the plot has been done far too many times before and for that reason in particular this film will be gone from my mind a week from now.

8/10 - with tremendous performances from Sarah Paulson and Kiera Allen, this horror-thriller proves Aneesh Chaganty (and the rest of his team responsible for this and 2018's Searching) is a new great of the genre

There are so many new films coming out this weekend and I hope that I can get them all in and I have decided to start with Netflix's new film Run and here is my review for it. The premise of the film sees a home-schooled student begin to suspect something isn't right with her mother and their living situation.Main Character
Sarah Poulson plays the mother in this film and she is really good. You can tell early on that something isn't quite right about her and Poulson manages to convey that without going over the top and making it a cheesy performance. It is a character where you shouldn't know anything about her going into the film as the mystery about what she is exactly up to is probably the best part of the film.Supporting Characters
Kiera Allen plays her daughter and I checked this is her first ever film and when you consider that she is remarkably good in the role. She is also confined to a wheelchair in real life, which I think adds way more impact to her performance. Her character is an easy one to root for and you really want her to work out what exactly is going and manage to have a happy ending. There isn't really any other characters in this film but some of the characters that have the odd scenes were really bad and took me out of the experience. I get that they hire unknown actors for these roles but maybe make sure they can deliver a realistic and normal scene.Story
The story is interesting, it kept me on edge throughout as you feel like you are similar to Allen's character as we really aren't sure what is exactly going on. Also there is a twist in the film as you would expect and I think it added plenty to the film and caught me off guard in a good way that it rose the quality of the product. But this films last act kind of lost me, its where the film starts to embrace the absurdity of everything and play it up but it is just too much and I think it is easily the least interesting part of the film.Script
The script is decent, the dramatic moments are well realised by the two actresses as they really build this dynamic that is interesting. But there is a lack of any humour and when you actually think it through, there is clear gaps in logic and things just don't always make sense.Style
The style of the film is really strong, the way it is directed and shot adds intrigue and suspense that a thriller truly needs. The pacing is really good with the film keeping me interested throughout and with it hitting 90 mins it doesn't overstay its welcome which is more then can be said for some films in the same genre.Overall
Overall, Run might be one of the biggest surprises so far in 2021. This is a good film that is suspenseful and intriguing, its not the best film ever but if you have Netflix and have 90 minutes you can do much worse then watching Run.

Kiera Allen lives in isolation with her mother Sarah Paulson. She is very smart but confined to a wheelchair with a number of illnesses. Where this is going is not entirely a mystery, but it's handled well, tension is maintained throughout and it builds well to a satisfying climax.

A solid but predictable thriller. A little disappointing as a follow up to Searching. Great debut from Kiera Allen.Director Aneesh Chaganty and co-writer Sev Ohanian struck gold with 2018's Searching. It's creative, original and gripping story hooked me from beginning to end. So it should go without saying that my level of excitement for their follow-up film Run would be quite high. Run felt like the kind of plot you'd find in a typical cable movie. Despite this, Sarah Paulson and Kiera Allen's performances were fantastic. Perhaps if the script had given us a bit more backstory to these characters, I would've felt more invested in the drama that enfolds between the 2nd and 3rd act.It's not to say that Run doesn't have some shining moments here and there. It's filmed exceptionally well for the most part and the scene at the pharmacy was well acted and intense. And while the execution of the final scene may have fallen short, I do appreciate the turnabout dynamic between mother and daughter.

Run: Some mothers will do anything to keep control over their daughters. In this case it even extends to giving the daughter animal muscle relaxants to keep her in a wheelchair. Good acting by Allen and Paulson in this horror/thriller which is Written and Directed by Aneesh Chaganty. 7/10.

To an extent, we've seen similar movies before. Within the first few minutes and the first couple scenes we can begin to guess the general narrative thrust - but we still get surprises in the details of how it plays out. Defying basic familiarity, 'Run' greatly succeeds in being fun, thrilling, and unsettling.The building suspense is intense, with each turn in the plot making us feel ever more uneasy. Even though we can see generally where it's headed, that doesn't dampen the growing anxiety we share with protagonist Chloe. It helps that the film is set almost entirely within the home this mother and daughter share, confines that aid the troubling air about it all. Where the setting shifts outside the home, it's for a very specific narrative purpose; there is no excess or needless indulgence here, only thrills. And to that point - the turn in the plot within the last 20-30 minutes, heading toward the climax, ramps up the thrills considerably, and it's absolutely entrancing.Throughout the length, no small detail is left unnoticed as a means to craft the story being told. This is true as much for those oddities Chloe discovers that raises her suspicion of her mother, Diane, as for the early focus on all the small minutiae of their daily life together. The screenplay is immersive, and all credit in the world to writer-director Aneesh Chaganty and writer/co-producer Sev Ohanian - 'Run' is captivating.Maybe I'm just imagining things, or projecting, but throughout the picture there's seemingly a hint of shadow that pervades the lighting. This lends a great deal to the frankly hair-raising atmosphere - as does the original score by Torin Borrowdale. The music complements the developing tension so well, and is still another noteworthy aspect of the feature.Above all, though, 'Run' is primarily a vehicle for its two stars, and therein lies its greatest success of all. Sarah Paulson has some noteworthy credits to her name, but her performance here as doting mother Diane is truly stellar. Even when not demonstrating alarming behavior or having an outburst of emotion, there is an unyielding intensity she gives the role that makes the twisted nature of the scenario all the more riveting. If I haven't looked for Paulson's name before, I surely will now.Yet even Sarah Paulson's marvelous performance is outshone by Kiera Allen, making her full-length film debut as afflicted protagonist Chloe. Allen is absolutely outstanding, making Chloe relatable, sympathetic, and as believably lifelike as a fictional character could be. I truly hope to see Allen in many more pictures in the future, because this is a powerhouse display of acting skill that deserves so much attention, accolade, and reward. She excellently portrays every frustration, anxiety, fear, panic, and resolve of the character, even with the limitations that the screenplay increasingly gives Chloe as the film progresses toward its conclusion. She should be so very proud of 'Run,' because she has impressed me in a way where I can't immediately draw any comparison.While one doesn't wish to linger on such things, it is necessary to mention so long as the film industry in general flags with little to no progress: There is a long-standing, appalling tendency in Hollywood and elsewhere toward casting that ignores performers fitting the demographic of a given role. One would think the lesson had been learned after blackface was relegated to shameful cinematic history, yet still diversity is lacking. Trans roles too often go to cis actors, gay roles to straight actors, or disabled roles to actors with no disability at all. It is to the credit of the filmmakers in this instance that they bucked this trend, and ever more so because in casting Kiera Allen as Chloe, they have exposed audiences to an astounding young actress. Hopefully, in so doing, they have opened her future to many, many more roles - to say nothing of the future of many other actors as well.To be honest, in the first few minutes after I began watching, I was a little bit skeptical. That the rudimentary gist of the plot seemed familiar had me second-guessing the viewing, and I lowered my expectations. But I am blown away: despite sharing a measure of kinship with other stories we've seen before, 'Run' stands so strongly of its own merit that I think it should be heralded as an exemplar.I don't generally give a feature a "perfect score" unless there's something about it that truly leaps out at me. Save perhaps for Paulson and Allen's performances, I don't know that there's a particular outlier here. Yet 'Run' is just so carefully, lovingly crafted as a whole, such a great film of its own accord, that I think it absolutely stands alongside the best of the best.Don't pass this up. Highest recommendation!

This is the story of a homeschooled teenager who is in a wheelchair and she begins to suspect her mother is keeping a dark secret from her.I can't remember how long it is since I watched a film as ridiculous as this .I'm not saying it isn't entertaining in parts but if films won awards for ridiculousness this would be a favourite to win .There is one scene where Chloe climbs over the roof of her house , bearing in mind she's disabled, to the outside of her mothers bedroom . She really does have that kind of face that lends herself to weird characters and Kiera Allen who is actually in a wheelchair in real life , is ok too but this won't be a film that stays with me for too long .

Review title: A mediocre thriller featuring a solid lead performance from Kiera Allen! [+52%]
Review_body: Aneesh Chaganty's second directorial effort is several notches below his first ('Searching'). All of the mystery and thrills get exhausted in the first 35 minutes and thereafter, it's a straightforward, predictably mediocre film. It's almost like the writers (Changanty himself & Sev Ohanian) ran out of ideas in the second half and what ends up on the screen is plot-holes galore. I mean, I simply cannot like a thriller where the antagonist stocks all evidence of her wrongdoings in a goddamn box for the protagonist to conveniently find them at a crucial juncture in the film. That's just ridiculous!The good thing to have come out of the weirdly titled 'Run' is Kiera Allen. She puts up a more-than-decent performance that keeps the first act and parts of the second mostly engaging. Sarah Paulson is fine as the creepy, protective mom but I wish her character had better detailing (those scars were such a useless decoy!) . In fact, some wide-angle shots are effectively chilling. It does offer a few big acting moments for Kiera Allen (who's a wheelchair-user in real life) but forgets to flesh out Paulson's character. 'Run' isn't a solid follow-up to 'Searching', but I'll still keep an eye out for Chaganty's next.

RUN (2020) was surprisingly better than I thought. I think it was originally meant to premiere in theaters until the COVID pandemic hit and delayed it among many major Hollywood productions. So it ended up on Hulu as one of their "original" movies. I'm still not 100% sure about how I feel on Sarah Paulson. While I generally think she's an actress who is very good at relaying deep emotions, there's also something annoying about her acting style as she has this languorous speech pattern like she's trying to hypnotize the person she's talking to. She's also famous for her nonstop crying and screaming. Anyone who has seen American Horror Story knows what I'm talking about. So, why, you ask, if I'm not the biggest Sarah Paulson fan (as so many people seem to be) am I rating this flick so highly? First, this is a very well done movie. Second, Paulson's hystrionics are dialed down immensely in this to the point I actually like her performance. Finally, Paulson is not the actual star of this piece. That honor goes to newcomer Kiera Allen in a brilliant film debut. It is Allen's character that really drives the plot.Run is the story of single mother Diane Sherman (Paulson) and her 17-year old daughter Chloe Sherman (Allen). Chloe was born with several debilitating birth defects, including paralysis, asthma, and diabetes. Diane has dedicated her life to care for Chloe, including home schooling, a strict dietary regimen, and supervising her medical care. A wheelchair-confined Chloe is pretty good at taking care of herself and is incredibly smart. Allen, who is actually disabled in real life, is a revelation as she is required to do many hair-raising physical stunts while still staying in character. And in actuality, Allen gets way more screen time than Paulson as the film is told almost completely from Chloe's POV. In particular, I like how incredibly smart and clever that Chloe is. Every move that makes feels like it's coming from a character with actual common sense. In fact, Chloe may be one of the smartest protagonists that I've ever seen in a horror movie. Plus, for once, the minor characters aren't dumb as a bag of rocks as they usually are in horror films.The first half of the film cleverly makes you wonder if there's really something off with Diane or is it all just in Chloe's mind. The second half pays it all off. It has an old-fashioned horror movie appeal with a very simple plot and believable characters. No tricks or silly special effects. Just a straightforward plot that allows the viewer to go along with Chloe on her journey of self-discovery as well as finding out the deal with her mother. Also, the ending is incredibly satisfying.
Come on... they had Sarah Paulson in the cast. It could've been WAY less predictable and cliché than all of these Saturday night PG-13 suspense flicks. Misery (1990) meets MEHsery.

Review title: RUN solidifies Aneesh Chaganty's place in Hollywood as a director to follow closely!
Review_body: If you enjoy reading my Spoiler-Free reviews, please follow my blog :)Aneesh Chaganty's Searching was enough to add its debutant director-screenwriter to my list of "filmmakers to follow closely". Run solidifies Chaganty's place in Hollywood as one of the most technically impressive directors working today. His undeniable talent allows him to effortlessly generate incredible suspense throughout the movie's entire runtime, and his second feature-film is no exception.Possessing the type of premise I enjoy the most in thrillers, Chaganty and Sev Ohanian's screenplay is packed with excruciatingly long takes, filled with extremely tense dialogues, shocking developments, and a brutal amount of pain. All are enormously elevated by one of the most physically-demanding, emotionally powerful performances I've seen in the last few years: Kiera Allen, who uses a wheelchair for mobility in real-life, turns her acting debut into a genuine, realistic display of the challenging obstacles people with her condition have to overcome daily.Sarah Paulson continues her trend of playing truly evil characters, and I advise her to keep following this dark path of phenomenal interpretations. Her interactions with Kiera are remarkably intense. Story-wise, even though the constant revelations are narratively shocking, most of the script's developments are somewhat predictable. However, the "movie logic" problems stretch believability to a point beyond my limit, ultimately becoming one of those films people will either deeply enjoy or really hate depending on how nitpicky they choose to be.I'm as moderate as I can be, and the truth is, I didn't really think about these logical issues during the actual viewing. Having in mind Run's brilliant technical attributes (notably Nick Johnson and Will Merrick's editing, and Torin Borrowdale's score), its two impressive lead performances, and its endless suspenseful atmosphere, I can't help but recommend it to every fan of the genre.Rating: B+

The final act blatantly puts forward more queries than answers and I despise it when that happens.Looking at all the possibilities such an intriguing concept might have offered, I am saddened to see the creators choosing a safe passage over an ambitious one. They had all the fundamental constituents to achieve a rather desired outcome. Be it the formidable performances from Sarah Paulson, Kiera Allen, or the self-evident technological prowess; quite frankly, they had everything to go that extra mile. Yet they have chosen not to!Now, don't get me wrong. This is still a well-made movie with an ample amount of positive things to take away. It's just that I believe it was entitled to a much better implementation. Especially, when the core storyline had plenty of potential in the first place!

Review title: A standard thriller that does work
Review_body: Aneesh Chaganty made a dazzling debut with Searching, a film which I really like. His sophomore effort, Run, is engaging but not as good.Run follows Chloe, a homeschooled and wheelchair-bound teenager who suspects her mother is harbouring a dark secret from her.Most films that I've seen take place over a computer screen did not utilise the medium to its full potential which is why Searching stood out to me. With Run, Chaganty goes for a more standard and simple thriller. Despite how restricted the film is in terms of scale, Chaganty makes use of the small scale to great effect. There are some great moments of tension executed well and a level of claustrophobia that emerges as a result of the confined area the film takes place in. Casting Kiera Allen, an actual wheelchair user, was a great choice. Scenes with her crawling on the floor were effective as the struggle was real which made it suspenseful. Her performance was also great especially considering this was her feature film debut. Sarah Paulson seems to love playing horrible people but I can't complain because she does such a good job playing them.My main problem with Run is how standard of a thriller it is. After it ended, the film didn't leave much of an impression on me since there wasn't really anything in particular that made this film special. It was a fun 90 minute film that was well made but aside from that, I don't see myself remembering it in the long run or wanting to revisit it. However, I'll still look forward to what Aneesh Chaganty makes in the future as I believe he's a promising director.

Review title: While not as inventive as Searching, Run is another well-directed, taut thriller
Review_body: Run proves that Chaganty and Ohanian are here to stay, and I'll watch anything they make. Run certainly doesn't come close to the lofty heights of Searching, one of my top 5 movies of 2018, but it delivers a satisfying, tense thriller in a short runtime. The plot is quite straightforward and is predictable, but the performances and direction keep us on the edge of our seat anyways. The basic story is pretty one-note and I'm not even sure if the advertising is trying to hide it. Even so, as you'd expect if you watched Searching, the attention to detail is excellent here. The set design is great, with small details throughout the house adding to the immersion. Paulson has a fun role that she thankfully doesn't go too off the rails with, but it is absolutely Allen who steals the show here. It was a great choice to get an actress who actually uses a wheelchair for the role, because the movements, especially quick ones when she's trying to get going quickly or be sneaky, would fall flat on their face if she wasn't deft in using the wheelchair. Not only are the wheelchair scenes completely natural, Allen's gradual turn from nervous bargaining to intense fear is fantastic. I really hope we see more from her in the future, because she'd honestly make my top 5 lead actresses of this year right now. The script isn't quite as tight as in Searching, and the final scene (with the line "open wide") was quite silly and detracts from the resolution up to that point. It's not a movie that will stay with me because it doesn't have enough to say psychologically or thematically, but I was nervous and completely engaged from start to finish.

Review title: Not Another Searching, But Great Filmmaking
Review_body:
"I... don't... need you."
"You will."A homeschooled teenager confined to a wheelchair due to many medical issues begins to suspect her mother is keeping a dark secret from her. This by itself is an interesting enough plot for potential. Then add Aneesh Chaganty and it's bound to be a success. Run is probably more popular than Searching already from the record breaking views on Hulu. All of us Searching fans have been waiting for this one for a while now. I'm sad to say Run doesn't quite hold up to the standards of Searching, but this is still a good movie. Sev Ohanian and Aneesh Chaganty know how to make a compelling story. Every step of the way I wanted to know what would happen next. How Searching filled itself up with mystery and twists till the end overpowers this one. Run's setup is not like that in which you know what is going to happen, but how it will unfold is the mystery. That's where it suffered for me. Just the expectations I had from the writers, directors, and raving reviews before its release had me with such high hopes. In the end I got a good movie, though.The performances is where the story shines most. Sarah Paulson has been the center of attention for this one because of American Horror Story and how well she does with horrors/thrillers. She is convincing, but because of the writing you know what's going to happen with her and everything. For her first feature, Kiera Allen does fantastic. We're with her mainly the whole time so we can really connect with her. Portraying all these health issues can be challenging for an actor. She makes it look almost easy with how well she did. I'm sure come Chainsaw Awards and all those, she'll be in conversation. I don't have much else to say about Run. It's good but didn't wow me. As a thriller, this is very entertaining and a good watch. The reviews might be a little generous but that's not to say this doesn't represent good filmmaking.

Is it very original? No. Is it good? Yes.Cinema how it should, good story, tense, beautifully shot (am I the only one who saw a lot of shots paying homage to some other cinema classics?), very well acted, and not even a bit over pretentious.

In the age of streaming, we've become accustomed to watching a fair share of uncomfortable thrillers that we otherwise wouldn't be exposed to. While most of these are straight up trash, a few are worth writing home about. 'Run' is one example.Starring the modern-day scream queen herself, 'Run' does a good job of diving deep down into the emotional profiles of a caretaker mother and her ill daughter. Character-driven thrillers such as this one must ride or die on the abilities of its actors, and Sarah Paulson lives up to her reputation as the strict mother who apparently devotes her life to caring for her daughter (played by Kiera Allen). Allen's portrayal of the confused Chloe is also admirable, and the two together are a formidable pair.Perhaps one of the best qualities of 'Run' is its limited range. It doesn't try to take a 180 degree turn, and even if there's a twist that can be seen coming from a backroad mile away, it doesn't feel offensive as these twists often can in low budget psychological thrillers. And while there are a few "are you serious?" scenes here and there, they aren't sold as being super serious.It's by no means a masterpiece, nor is it uplifting, but 'Run' is pretty entertaining at face value.

Review title: FROM THE DESK OF GEORGE WASHINGTON
Review_body: Good Morrow.Another Munchausen by proxy flick...this time with Sarah Paulson, who I've had quite enough of. In this, you are asked to believe that a baby can be whisked away from a Maternity Ward.Have any of those involved with the production of this ever been to a Maternity/NICU ward in the USA within the last 35 years? Not likely.They are all - without exception - a locked unit. Often, you need to be badged in and sign in with ID...and the ones in my area (DC), you are wrist-banded. Also, the baby is banded with a chip and that chip will set off alarms if removed from the area.You are never alone - you are not allowed access to the babies unsupervised...and there are cameras and security everywhere.The idea of waltzing out of one with a newborn is ridiculous & if you did manage it, you'd be apprehended immediately. It's preposterous...but there you.Also, if you're a psychopath who intends to imprison your daughter forever, why would you bother to mail the college applications in the first place? I'll tell you, so at one point the kid can find one.At one point, the kid sneaks out of her bedroom window, drags herself over the shingles to her mom's room, all the while lugging along extension cords, a soldering iron, and a mouth full of water...she plugs it in and BINGO - it's all warmed up (they take minutes)...she heats the glass and spits the water shattering the glass...makes sense since she has a room full of tools and could have broken the glass in a much easier way. All this to show how ingenious she is. Then the geniuses behind this mess gave her the most cliched medical issue - the inhaler trope. Of course, she starts having breathing problems...and of course, she reaches her inhaler just in time. Whew! For a minute there, I didn't think she was gonna make it. Edge of your seat stuff.This movie expects too much from any viewer with intelligence...but I'm giving it a three, because it had dummy popcorn element to it and I thought the wheelchair kid (who's actually disabled), did a good job.Cheers.

Overall rating 93/100Run is about a disabled home-schooled girl called Chloe (Kiera Allen) who is waiting to get results to get into her college, but when she gets nothing she begins to suspect her overprotective mother is keeping a dark secret from her. What an intense film Run was, I was on edge from beginning to end, so let's get started.Firstly, I thought the movie itself was a really interesting idea, I think it had a great set up and character background, as well as having great sound design and cinematography. The movie's premise itself was really interesting and had me hooked straight away, it set up the mystery straight away with the mother and was an effective psychological thriller premise with the family dynamic. I also found the set up really interesting, the movie did an excellent job at suspending the audiences disbelief in terms of setting up normality between the mother and daughter relationship and making you believe that there was nothing wrong happening this just added to the tension that was slowly built up. I also really appreciated the character background and set up for both Sarah Paulson and Kiera Allen's character, we understood the mothers troubled past and near death experience with her child and the connection she had to her daughter, but we also got a good establishment of both of their routines together and how Chloe deals with her disabilities which I loved. I also thought that the sound design for this movie was excellent, it was intensified and loud when it needed to be to keep you on edge and was used very effectively. I also really loved the cinematography involved, due to the movie mostly being limited to roughly one set location they used every aspect of the house very well and had multiple very creative shots, especially with the mother in the background of the frame in order to build tension so they still managed to make it seem fresh and creative whilst still mostly only being in one location which was great.My next few positives would be the tense tone and building of tension, fantastic performances, the positive representation of disability, as well as the strong script. The movie managed to achieve an excellent tense tone, the events and the correlation with the mother got more and more uncomfortable and tense and I loved it, the movie took its time and built the tension effectively over time. The performances were also fantastic, both Kiera Allen and Sarah Paulson did a fantastic job here, Sarah plays darker roles excellently, her performance was uncomfortable, powerful and she really bought the character to life, Kiera Allen was also fantastic, she got so into the role she managed to create a big reaction from me in terms of really sympathising with her character which proves that her performance was powerful and believable. I also thought the movie had very positive representation for disability, they showed effectively how Chloe didn't let her disability from stopping her and she still had a positive outlook on everything, this kind of positive representation of disability within films should be kept up because its nice to see. Finally, I also thought the script was very strong, the movie didn't go over the top or so farfetched that it wasn't realistic, most of the scenes were logical and made sense and actually took into account the characters limitations it just made it more tense to watch as it didn't take you out of the movie and never got too ridiculous, I also thought the script was structured very well to build tension and the dialogue was effective.My two slight negatives for the movie would be its lack of establishing the two leads relationship and the occasional predictable or odd character decision. I did think the movie had slightly rushed pacing at the beginning, it would have been nice if the movie spent more time expanding and developing the positive relationship between the mother and daughter instead of the slightly repetitive beginning and teasing something sinister straight away an extra ten/fifteen minutes would have done the trick. I also thought that the film occasionally slipped into genre tropes with some predictable or odd character decisions, there was a few decisions from the characters especially Chloe that were very predictable in order to progress the plot and some odd decisions to be so open with her mother even when she suspects her that weren't logical but this was only occasionally and thankfully not all the time.My next few positives would be the clever character decisions to build tension, the jumpscares, character depth and amazing plot twists. I thought that the character of Diane played by Sarah Paulson was so clever and manipulative in turning the narrative to make her daughter seem insane or to make herself look better it built the tension between both characters very well and was very cleverly written. The movie also had very effective jumpscares, it didn't rely on them which I loved as it was more about the dark themes and the tense atmosphere, but the jumpscares that were used were effective, shocking and took me by surprise so were therefore not predictable and well set up. I also thought the character depth for Diane was excellent, when the movie showed her losing her child and her stealing the child all the pieces meshed together, I understood despite the insanity of the character her point of view and her genuinely believing she was helping her because she didn't want to lose her new daughter gave the character some much needed if not slightly disturbing character depth. Finally, the plot twists were truly shocking and amazingly executed, wow I didn't see those twists coming, I knew something more sinister was at work but where the movie went with the characters I was just not expecting it, I was slowly more and more entertained and on edge as the movie went on.My final couple of positives would be the amazing final act and the shocking ending. The movie final act was just incredible, it was intense, powerful brilliantly acted and I genuinely didn't know what the outcome would be that is when you know a movie is well written and constructed, I also found the ending very shocking the role reversal between the mother and daughter was unexpected but the message was conveyed clearly and the shocking effects of her mothers cruelty to her was on full display in a twisted but satisfying ending.Overall, Run Is an extremely intense, frightening and clever movie with a strong script and fantastic performances from Sarah Paulson and Kiera Allen. It made me on edge from beginning to end, it fell into a few horror/psychological thriller tropes but for the most part was a refreshing and intense film that worked very well, I would recommend!

Review title: Very effective, well acted little thriller.
Review_body: Run had bern a film that I had heard good things about but hadn't gotten around to watch it. I have to say that I was impressed by how well made and tight the film is and how it uses all of its 90 minutes to great suspenseful effect. It is a very simple premise but done very well.Run stars Sarah Paulson as Diane. A woman who is seen in the beginning of the film having just given birth to a premature baby. It seems tgat the child had many health problems. The film forwards to 17 years later. We learn that her daughter Chloe, played by Kiera Allen. She is bound to a wheelchair. She has many health problems and doesn't leave her house without her mother who apparently take good care of her. She is homeschooled and very intelligent. Her mother Diane seems to be very devoted and protective of her daughter. Chloe starts getting curious and startes investigating the medicines she's taking and her mother gers more protective and prevents her from using the internet at night and limits her phone calls. She's hiding something and Chloe sets out to find out more. No more spoilers. Needless to say this film is very involving and suspenseful. The performances by both women are excellent. Especially by Kiera Allen, who is actually in a wheelchair in real life. Her performance is really good. Sarah Paulson is extremely effective as the over protective mother with something to hide.The film is directed by Aneesh Chaganty. He directed the excellent thriller Searching with John Cho. That film's premise is also very simple and bare bones but he knows how to create great suspense with good performances and effective atmosphere. There are some plot points that are far fetched in Run but they are necessary for suspense. I was completely invested in the story. I hope to see more from Aneesh Chaganty in the future.Very good thriller.Grade: B+

Review title: Thrilling thriller with good and appropriate acting.
Review_body: Run is a new thriller directed and written in part by Searching director Aneesh Chaganty.The film is about the teenage girl Chloe (Kiera Allen), who is in a wheelchair and who is further educated and cared for by her mother Diane (Sarah Paulson). When Chloe feels her mother is acting strangely, she tries to find out what's going on. She learns that her mother is trying to keep a dark secret from her that she must unravel from her wheelchair.This film comes across as a psychological thriller where you as a viewer don't know what exactly is going on or which of the characters is telling the truth. Thanks to the story, the film is quickly reminiscent of the book by Stephen King Misery, which also has a film of the same name. The film is also self-aware of this, as there are some hidden hints in the film that link back to Misery's story as well as to other Stephen King stories. The story of this film can seem a bit familiar and if you think about it, it can miss some details. This way you can enjoy the film more if you don't think about everything too much.The acting is done well and appropriately by the film cast. Kiera Allen is disabled by an unexpected complication, forcing her to live in a wheelchair. Together with the filmmakers, she saw this as the right opportunity to play in this film. Kiera herself saw this as a good challenge to finally play a big film role from her small theater roles. Hopefully, thanks to this role, she will be able to break through in the film world. Sarah Paulson also delivers good acting as a nurturing mother who also hides a dark side. She knows how to switch between these two different sides of her character.

You would call the damn child support services is what you would do, but then the movie would be over, and we can't have that.*Spoilers end*I mentioned that because that was by far the dumbest scene of the whole film to me, but there are quite a few moments that had me thinking it was pretty bloody stupid. ExcerptRun is a psychological thriller with a hint of horror that presents some scenes of extraordinary tension, posed and solved with ingenuity. The film sports a suspense that never wanes, but clearly wins when it focuses on its disabled protagonist and the challenges he faces (a notable portrayal of newcomer Kiera Allen) and becomes more conventional in the scenes they share with his mother (Sarah Paulson).-------------------------------------------------- -----------------------------------------ReviewRun begins with a disturbing prologue: Diane (Sarah Paulson) observing her newborn daughter and warning herself of the illnesses and disabilities she will suffer.An ellipsis leads us to Diane and her teenage daughter Chloe (Kiera Allen) living in a comfortable and secluded house. Both have incorporated the routines derived from the treatment of the various pathologies of Chloe, who is anxiously waiting for an acceptance email to start her university life. But the young woman will soon begin to enter the terrain of doubts and mistrust.Aneesh Chaganty's film starts from the psychological drama to delve into the thriller with hints of terror, with a suspense that does not wane. The best parts of the film are those by Chloe, with an exceptional performance by newcomer Kiera Allen. The psychic and physical challenges that the plot poses to the young woman are thoughtfully posed and resolved through situations that generate a lot of tension; these scenes constitute the best of the film (the soundtrack, at times, accompanies very well). But the story becomes more conventional and even melodramatic in the sections where Chloe interacts with her mother.As often happens lately in many films that begin with good plans and well-constructed and dosed initial sections, at times in this one the credible one is in danger of being shipwrecked, even in the case of a genre film. And unnecessarily, too.However, in the final section, the director and the script somehow achieve a synthesis, successfully reconciling all aspects of a film that brings together more than one topic from the Stephen King universe.

Review title: A Thriller That Was Actually Thrilling!
Review_body: Run is the newest Hulu original film. It was originally supposed to come out on mothers day but then got moved to November. If I saw this on mothers day, I wouldn't have wanted to spend time with my mother.Run is about a mom named, Diane (Sarah Paulson) who is really protective of her daughter, Chloe (Kiera Allen) because of how sick she is. Her daughter then suspects that her mom is keeping a dark secret from her.Run was a film I wasn't planning on watching because I don't have Hulu and it didn't seem like something to get Hulu for. I still wouldn't get Hulu just for this movie but that doesn't mean its bad. I was at a cabin that had Hulu and I watched this film at the cabin. I was utterly surprised. I thought this film wasn't going to be that good but ended up being something much better. To start, the story was wonderfully crafted. From start to finish it had me on the edge of my seat. The only thing I didn't like about the story was one little bit at the end. I just thought it didn't need to be there at all. Besides that the story was wonderful. It was cool to see how the mother and daughter bonded at the start. It showed that they both actually did care for each other at one point.The acting in the film was probably the best part. Kiera Allen as the disabled girl was a fantastic choice. She needs a wheel chair in real life so it added to the performance a lot. I bet if they got someone else that wasn't in a wheel chair, the part would have been portrayed a lot differently. Sarah Paulson gave a marvelous performance. She always plays such a creepy person in movies. This film wasn't her best but it was a darn good performance. The daughter and mother were really the only two actors in the film besides for some other little parts that some characters had.As I said in the title, this film is actually thrilling. There are a lot of movies that just aren't scary at all that have been coming out. The two films this year that actually freaked me out are Run and His House. His House is a marvelous film I would defiantly recommend checking out. This film was a nail biter though. It had you asking many questions to your self during the movie about character decisions. The main character wasn't dumb or anything but the mom was the one that made you think. There were also some really intense sequences were the main character had to get something done but the mom was pretty close to her. Those always make me freak out a little bit. Overall, the film was incredibly intense.Run put you in the shoes of the main character and got you onto the edge of your seat. I would recommend this film to anybody that likes thrillers or if you have Hulu. It is defiantly one of the best films of the year.

Review title: When life gives you pills, you either open wide or question what you're getting
Review_body: "Run" is a more tame movie than one would expect. We get to follow a wheelchair-bound teenager, who also suffers from other life-threatening conditions. Her name is Chloe and she is a badass and she was one even before having to deal with the horrific situation in the movie. With all the handicaps, she still strived for proper education and I've got to admit, her engineering skills are far superior to mine, even though I completed 4 years of physics and engineering education. Well, mostly physics, I only had a few courses in engineering, electronics, telecommunications, and electrodynamics, but I wasn't a good student and anything about 3D printer wiring would be foreign for me. Going back to Chloe, she displayed advanced problem-solving skills that are impressive, to say the least.The plot was rather simple and short but it still had a plethora of memorable moments. One of those came around the middle of the movie. It goes to the category that has no name but can be described as a "scene that starts with you thinking what the hell is the character doing and ending with you thinking that is actually clever, leaving you feeling stupid to doubt the character". Jeez, that's a long name... Either way, the scene I had in mind was the one where Chloe used a bunch of extension cords, a soldering iron, a cloak, and a mouth full of water to escape her room. If you haven't watched this movie - no, I haven't made this up and you have to watch the movie to figure out how this works. This scene is clever in multiple ways but seeing how our protagonist has a handicap of not being able to walk too just makes it even more impressive. Besides that scene, we had many revelations that are either predictable or just come off as natural to the plot but everything fits the entertainment spectrum.(I'll just use this space to also mention that the actress Kiera Allen, who played Chloe here, uses a wheelchair in real life too.)What failed to impress me was the amount of the role of mother. Don't get me wrong, Sarah Paulson did a phenomenal job playing her but in the end, I can't think of a better word to describe her as a Karen. Some people might be offended by the use of that word but that's just the best word for the verb of an entitled egotistic woman that I know. I knew that she was hiding something from the movie description but the way she treats her "daughter" is saddening. It was good for the plot but her reasoning was questionable and barely motivated by anything that isn't selfish. In a way, she is a true villain in every sense of that word. But on the other hand, she has so many layers of plot armor that it's impressive that she made it to the end of the movie without being caught for her devious actions. The pharmacy, the altercation with the mailman, the hospital... the amount of red flags that she is actually dangerous and her daughter is in danger is impressive, I won't lie, but it's also absurd. The only thing that would make her character work crazily was if Chloe managed to finish her message, someone actually stayed in her room (seriously, there must always be someone present when treating attempted-suicide victims) and she still managed to get an upper hand. In this scenario, the psychotic determination would make her villain arc come full circle, instead of just giving her open doors to do what she pleases all the way.Overall, I can't say I disliked this movie. It's good even, though ranking it with other movies I liked is difficult. It's short in comparison, barely reaching 90 minutes, and it's rather an easy watch that doesn't leave any ambiguous messages or any cravings for more action. It's a decent dish that provides that fulfills your needs and doesn't leave you craving for seconds. If you're looking for something casual to watch, this is a good choice. Some say that this is a horror but from my perspective - it's not. It starts as a mystery but ends as a thriller. No jump scares or gore is involved. The only things that might be difficult to swallow are some taboo subjects but nothing here ever goes off the rails with crazy.

Sarah is an incredible actress, and Kiera also shows a great acting on it. It's agonizing, the kind of movie that the viewer feels the character agony. Although, it's a little too fast and, because of that speed, a little predictable.

Review title: Sarah Paulson plays a terrific antagonist
Review_body: A very entertaining thriller that makes you feel for the protagonist. With crafty planning and clever twists and plots. It's jam packed with a thrilling story and an incredible performance by Sarah Paulson who succeeds in playing a bad person.

While the acting isn't bad, the storyline has a lot of holes. Why would anyone kidnap a baby and keep the newspaper article in a box? What happened to the mailman, what happened to his van? The daughter obviously had strong upper body strength yet no fighting back. If the daughter suspected the green pils and others were being given criminally, then why not just stop taking them. The ending is ok but the lead up to it is frustrating.
I'm writing this within 5 minutes of watching this film.Superbly done and portrayed throughout.Compelling and invloving.

Review title: Predictable and seen it before, but still an OK thriller
Review_body: It's Friday night, dark and cold outside and Taco on my plate, let's go! Alright thriller, easy and enjoyable enough. Nothing new and it's pretty predictable, at least for me. My buddy didn't see is as that predictable, but he has seen 1/10 of movies I have seen. Anyways, good acting and good story, even if it has been recycled again. I still enjoyed it a little bit.You pretty much get what you expect. I feel 6.5/10 is fair

A little movie in every way. It is almost unknown forces behind the film, with only Sarah Paulsen who has some experience. The film knows its visiting time, and with a running time of 1h20min is a relatively short film. That's good, because it probably would not have lasted for a longer playing time.
The acting is really good and it's a damn good choice to cast Kiera Allen. Firstly because she is a wheelchair user, and secondly because she is exceptionally good. She needs to be watched. There are a few flaws in the film in terms of when she gets the pills and the fact that she has been paralyzed for a long time.
The twist is cool, but the film also jumps into a lot of typical family thriller clichés. Fortunately, the film does not fall into jumpscares.
There is a subplot with a star-shaped scar on the mother's back that is never explained, and a deleted scene should have explained it. But if a scene can explain an entire plot, then is it worth having?
A really sensible film, which with a little luck will be Kiera Allen's starting shot. I just fear the movie is not going to be great.

Critical for the life of a young girl
Once revealed the dark mind of a woman suffering of her real child lose, shows how cruel a human can be
What a wheelchaired girl will risk to get out free and alive?

Antagonist and protagonist are pretty well acted and the storyline is OK although it's been done better in several other films (I'm thinking Misery, 10 Cloverfield Lane, The Room) Run is a passable, average film with some tense moments, and some good pace and yet sadly it fell apart in the second and third acts after a decent opening.

"Fuja" é um filme novo do Netflix em que o forte não é a criatividade ou inovação (certamente) mas é um ótimo suspense. Recomendo. Run is a new Netflix film in which the strong point is not creativity or innovation (certainly) but it is a great suspense. I recommend it. #movieslover #netflix.

Among the big budget and big name releases ,Aneesh Chaganty's ('Searching") Run released in Hulu.Aneesh Chaganty has set his bars high with an amzingly well made film "Searching"in his debut and so anticipations were high.
If compared with Searching,Run is a disappointment but it's still an engaging watch.The film has hardly anything to add to it's plot if you have watched the trailer but that doesn't take away anything from the tense moments in the film.Chaganty has used silence i.e lack of any music in some parts of the film quite effectively,there were some moments where you couldn't take your eye away from the screen.
Kiera Allen(a real life handicapped girl) has been impressive in her debut and Ms Paulson has been menacing as a creepy woman.The film lacks character buildups and has spend more times in creating moments rather than adding anything new to the story.
Aneesh Chaganty is really a man to watch out for in the future.According to sources,he and his co writer Sev Ohanian are developing a script for the sequel for Searching

This is a decent enough thriller. However, you have to suspend reality occasionally as some scenes are just unbelievable. But if you have nothing better to do, then this movie will keep you mildly entertained for a couple of hours.

Review title: A thoroughly enjoyable film which kept us anxious throughout
Review_body:
We have just finished watching Run (2020) and thoroughly enjoyed it. A film that kept us on the edge of our seat, and one where I occasionally found my leg anxiously tapping during the tense scenes.Run isn't going to win any Oscars, but few films are made for this pretentious award - an accolade given to garbage such as The Shape of Water (2017) - feel free to read my review for it.So the good and the bad:
The actresses are well cast and the acting was spot onThe film is well made with a good script and the right toneThe film is short, but works extremely well this wayIn truth there is nothing I would change about Run. It's well made, the script is good and the acting fine.The film closely resembles Misery (1990) and although not of the same brilliance, it is still very good. Recommended!

Review title: Suspend disbelief and it is.... better
Review_body: I thought it seemed fine until the unbearable pharmacy scene followed by other also unbearable, illogical scenes to follow. The atmosphere and acting is good, no complaints there, and it was very cool that the lead actress is actually wheelchair bound and not just someone pretending, but that doesn't fix plotholes and really bad writing unfortunately. Not a horrible way to burn time but not a real gem, as others said it is similar to Misery and the real life case of Gypsy Blanchard.

Run is well acted thriller full of tension. An homeschooled teenager who begins to suspect her mother is keeping a dark secret from her. Sarah Paulson and Kiera Allen are insanely good. The movie has unfortunately a bad and quick end. However Aneesh Chaganty made a gripping low budget thriller.Rating: 7,2.

Run is only 90mins, so it starts quickly and moves nicely along at a tempo that won't make you want to look away.Acting is great all round from a small cast. The story does twist and turn and keeps you guessing as to what is going to happen next and how it will all end.Run is definitely worth watching for non-action thriller fans although there is some effective action scenes when it is needed. It's gripping and very effective.

This is the story of a paralyzed girl. She is very sick and she is taking many medications per day. One day she realizes that there is something wrong with her medications. She suspects her mom who is taking care of her. She tries to figure out what is wrong, and this is when the story kind of starts. The story is amazing and innovative. Kiera Allen and Sarah Paulson played very well in this movie. The sound effects and background music is awesome. Most of the story is happening in a house. But, some of the stories happen in other locations. In summary, if you are a fan of horror and thriller genres, I recommend this movie to you.

Review title: If you liked Misery you might like this one
Review_body:
Although the twist is well expected for from this movie's premise, it is a bone-chilling moment when the main character (played by Kiera Allen) found outs her true origins and who her mom really is.Acting in this one is quite good and Sarah Paulson successfully (even though not brilliantly) tackles the hard job of transitioning from a seemingly caring mom to a very demented person towards the end of the movie. I found the story to be intriguing and believable along with the acting makes this a pretty solid movie.
The ending of such movie is important. I don't think the director have nailed it in this case, since obviously the mom will be locked down for good for a murder, nobody really cares under which terms that is. I would have been nice to see her biological parents in the picture, for example and if they filmed any 'alternative ending' scenes.
Overall I feel the IMDB crowd is right, this film scores in the middle 6's and my exact score: 65 / 100

Make that Mental illness caused Physical illness.First of all, if a movie can get my attention for first 20 minutes, this movie most likely will get the passing mark of 5 stars!Second, this movie does build some suspense as it goes on.There are many unanswered questions in the story. Viewers will have to guess, but the basic theme or plot is about mental illness I think. This woman lost what she had and tried to protect what she possessed by doing the wrong thing.Love in this case is beyond the protection. It is possession.Overall, the movie is good. However, there are quite a few goofs in the movie.

Review title: Added additional value to my Hulu membership.
Review_body: As has happened several times before, an interview with the director and lead actor on NPR put this movie on my do-list. It was a real treat for an evening watch. As I expected, the story was crisp and engaging, containing just enough exposition to jump start the tense story. The acting was uniformly excellent, and pulled me in exactly as the director intended. There were a few plot holes, but like a car racing down a rough road pavement, the taught pacing causes the viewer fly over those rough spots. As a film in the "thriller" catagory, it gets the job done!

Review_body: But there's enough differences to make for an engaging film. Can't really say anything bad about it, you know what your getting into and it delivers with rising tension and suspense.

What a great hidden gem of a film, at least for me. I had not really heard of this one as I think it kinda fell through the cracks due to COVID but glad I found it. This had a combination of Rear Window and The Act with a little bit of Misery rolled into one. Very suspenseful and quite smart at times too. Kiera Allen was great in her debut and I'm glad they hired an actual disabled person, it gave more authenticity to the film. I was not bored at all watching this but felt that the ending was a little rushed. As a whole, this movie is more than a one time watch.

Review title: It's a story we've all seen time and again, nothing really new here.
Review_body: Some scenes were very predictable and dragged on for too long. The very last minute of the film offered an interesting "twist" if you can call it that, but it was way too far-fetched to be even remotely believable given the circumstances etc. I would say the first act of the movie is the most enjoyable. The introduction to our two characters was done well. There are some things that can be easily nit-picked but it is just a movie and I guess it's not meant to be taken so seriously. All in all, I did enjoy it. Sarah Paulson is great and the other actress did a good job as well.
The movie I thought is quite predictable. There is still however some element of suspense. I didn't mind it, the acting is good.

* There is no end credit scene *The director Aneesh Chaganty and crew brought an overfamiliar storyline. The story sets when a homeschooled teenager begins to suspect that her overprotective mother is keeping a secret from her. I wasn't intrigued when I watched the trailer because it was a film that has been done so many times and it feels like he took an idea from every drama movie surrounded by this storyline and added it all into his film. I expected more from him since his directional debut Searching (2018), was fantastic and even though this was a common film I thought maybe there was a twist but sadly it was already done before making it annoying and predictable.The composer Torin Borrowdale knows how to really set the thriller atmosphere. No matter how repetitive the movie was I was impressed by the suspense in certain scenes and the music set it perfectly making me feel very edgy.Sarah Paulson and Kiera Allen's performances were fantastic but I couldn't deeply feel for the mother because it lacked depth in the script making me not be able to feel for her situation. By not having her have more depth it created a chain of events of me not be able to feel for the daughter as well. Aside from the needed missing depth in the storyline which is not their fault, both of them were still incredibly gripping especially Kiera Allen.

This could have been really good for what it is intended to be: a film that is not going to win any awards, but is good enough to keep you satisfyingly engaged.Lamentably, it was not.While the story is good, and the acting on ALMOST every front is excellent, EVERY SINGLE TIME in which Chloe (Kiera Allen) had to move to or from her wheelchair looked SO ridiculously FAKE, that it immediately pulled me out of what we were watching. It was obvious that the actress had full use of her legs and was moving them, and that the director or crew did not bother to perfect what they were trying to sell (that she is paralyzed) was just shoddy work and ruined the entire film for me.
Sarah Paulson plays her characters beautifully. The film itself is unpredictable, from start to finish. Reminds me of a real story, with a completely different subtext.
Totally inspired by the series i mentioned on the title, totally predictable, yet pretty awesome. A ten for me, cause it kept me in tention, and anxious.

Review title: Yup, disturbing but appreciate the acting
Review_body: This movie makes you think some kids will probably be safer if they had a cellphone or internet, and it's difficult to believe a girl who's about to go to college doesn't have these things to interact with the outside world and yet still "happy and normal". Maybe set the year back to the 80s and it'll seem more natural.All hell of suspicious broke loose just because of one pill. I guess if you take something long enough you kind of forget why you're taking it until you really stop and question about your wellbeing. It's a new pill but that's just the tip of the icerberg that got the ball rolling.As I'm writing this I'm still not convinced that a girl being overprotected and poisoned for 17 years can be happy. They ought to be miserable. And since the Mother did help her live through it all and now on the path to college, this makes the Mother even more creepy what she's been actually doing. Although acting is good, but she doesn't strike me as the mental illness type.The story went downhill when the incompetent mailman failed to rescue the girl. Small town guy didn't even put up a fight and lingering when his intuition clearly knows something's wrong. Yeah, you see a 17 year old girl like that, take her to the police immediately, you stupid. I know the movie had to reel her back into the house, but there are much better ways to do it that could add a lot of points.I strongly suggest to make an alternate ending, without the current creepy "I'm doing this to you in a wheelchair 'cause you did it to me for the last 17 years". This idea is from another movie, can't remember which one on top of my head. It's not necessary, and overthrows the whole point of barely surving a catastrophe. The right ending should be a healthy girl getting her wishes and graduating from college soon to be hired by an institution specializes in helping disabled people. Or, that engineering thingy she was really into back in her room to connect the dots. With the current ending, now, I feel like it's hereditary and those two are really related afterall.Good acting.

Review title: A Thin Veneer Over Very Little
Review_body: There was no progression from a lifetime of being a trusting daughter, to rabid suspicion, it all seemed to boil down to one pill and that's just not enough to retain reality.I'm sorry to say that by the end of the film, it felt like this was simply made as a vehicle for a real life wheelchair user to have as main part in a film and overcome it, pathetic and patronising.It's Ok if you have very low standards.
